1.summary: Lack of connection to robust optimization and no formal justification for why the method improves consistency.
1.verbatim: The paper does not draw a connection to prior work on robust optimization... it would be good to give a formal definition of robustness/consistency and cite this line of prior work. The paper does not provide a clear justification for why P-Adapters would be expected to improve consistency, and nothing in the training objective encourages the model to be consistent.

2.summary: Limited empirical validation beyond the specific benchmark.
2.verbatim: As this paper notes, the factual probing benchmark has class imbalances and represents a very particular use case, so while P-Adapters appear to improve consistency here itâ€™s unclear if these results will generalize to other settings. Would it be possible to evaluate P-Adapters on a wider variety of tasks?

3.summary: No human evaluation to support claims about user preferences.
3.verbatim: Much of the motivation of this paper is based on assertions about user preferences, but there is no human evaluation to validate these claims.

4.summary: Concerns about relation classifier accuracy and omission in the main paper.
4.verbatim: MoE model: How accurate is the relation classifier?... Either way, relation classification results should be included and discussed in the main paper.

5.summary: Performance drop on 'OOD Objects' indicates overfitting to entity distribution.
5.verbatim: All of the models suffer a performance drop on the 'OOD Objects' setting, which indicates that the models have over-fit to the (imbalanced) distribution of entities in Wikidata.

6.summary: Lack of comparison with prior work in results table.
6.verbatim: Table 2 does not compare results to any prior work. For example, can these results be compared to the 'Consistency Improved PLM' results from [5]?
